Posts.Title: Dr. Leo, another question when you have time....

Posts.Content: Hey, Sweetie, It's tragic that your friend died; I am so sorry for your loss. I realize that you were not best friends, but you were connected through your other friend, and we all sort of live in a web of interconnections. There are no rules about who can mourn for who, or how close a friend you have to be. You liked her, you admired her, you thought she was nice and funny. If you are affected, you are affected, you don't really get to choose. I think it probably would be bad taste to carry on in public as if you were best friends, since you don't want people to think you are attaching yourself to a tragedy for other reasons, but it's certainly ok to express your sadness and to mourn her. Just be genuine. Sometimes, it's only when someone is gone that we realize how much we liked or admired someone, when we feel a void within ourselves, and a regret that we had not spent more time with the person or appreciated them more. As to your friend, who was close with the girl who died, I cannot say how she will react. I would think that she is very sad now and trying to deal with it. But it's ok to talk to people when they are sad, if they feel like talking. I think that you can call her, and say something really simple like, hi, I've been thinking about you, this is so sad, and you were so close. I really don't know what to say, I just wanted you to know that I was thinking about you ... If she wants to talk more, she will, if not, it's ok. You just want her to know that you care how she feels. It is hard to talk about these things, and it is harder when you are so young and, thank goodness, haven't had alot of experience with it. But I think that your friend will appreciate knowing that you care about her, and that you cared about the girl who died, and sometimes, that's all that's necessary. You don't have to pry, you don't have to tell her it will be ok, because it won't, not for a long time. If she wants to talk about her, you should listen. Really listen. If she wants to share her feelings, that will be good. But don't push. The other side of this is, if you don't call her, she may feel alone and abandoned. And maybe she really wants to talk about her friend. Another thing about this very tragic death, is of course that she is too young to die. It is very rare in our society for teenagers to die, and especially from a disease. It upsets what we think of as the natural order. Teenagers shouldn't get sick and die. Older people do, but kids don't. And when it does happen, it scares us. It particularly scares you when you are the same age. You feel like, this could have been me. This is not like the death of a grandparent. So it is certainly ok to mourn, to be sad. You may want to go to the funeral. And also, if you want, you can write a note to her parents. You can say that you liked her and shared a class with her, that she was nice, and she was funny, and that you regret not having known her better. These are nice things to do when someone dies, it helps the ones who are left. And you can write a note to your friend also. Sorry if I ramble. Rachel

Posts.Title: Hello. Could you help me?

Posts.Content: Roberta, I had dose dense chemo, which is 4 AC, then 4 Taxol, 2 weeks apart. I also had Neupogen shots for seven days on days 3-10 to keep my white blood count up. If you have chemo every 3 weeks, the timing may be different. My hair started coming out in hunks on day 16, and I shaved on day 17. I didn't lose my eyebrows or eyelashes until the Taxol phase. It is the adriamyacin that kills the head hair, by the way. rachel

Posts.Title: FIRST DOSE OF CHEMO

Posts.Content: There is a special massage that you can get that really helps - my cousin swears by it (they took out 40 nodes - the doctor said Oops, sorry!). It is lymphedema massage, it is feather light, and the light strokes go from the extremities to the shoulder direction, which helps the lymph exit. This is NOT deep tissue or strong massage. Google "lymphedema massage" and you will find alot of info. See http://www.cancerpage.com/centers/Si...lymphedema.asp , which says in part: "The National Lymphedema Network (www. Lymphnet.org) encourages massage by an specially certified expert in lymphedema massage.. In many cases, patients can also be trained to massage themselves to improve the flow of lymph fluids. " See also http://www.massagetherapy101.com/mailbag13.aspx for info also.

Posts.Title: lymphedema

Posts.Content: Hi Danielle, I think that you ought to double-check that diagnosis. "Infiltrating" is used differently sometimes, and is not necessarily the same as "invasive". My path report said infiltrating DCIS. I grilled my doc, and he said emphatically that what I had was NOT IDC. Infiltrating DCIS is a higher grade than just DCIS, but it is not Invasive Ductal Carcenoma (IDC). Hope that helps. Be strong. She is going to get through this just fine! And she will live to be an old lady!

Posts.Title: My mom just found out

Posts.Content: I finished all treatment a year ago (LB mastectomy, chemo, radiation) for Stage 3A. (IDC nuclear grade 1, DCIS grade 2, 7 nodes) My onc just does blood tests every 3 months, nothing else. He says the other tests I asked about have high false positives and are more trouble than they are worth. I have regular mammograms and breast MRIs, PAPs. I just had a bone density test. My breast surgeon mentioned a CT scan and an ultrasound of the ovaries, but don't know what to do with that information. This doesn't seem like it's enough! Do I have to wait until my bones hurt to find out I have bone mets? What tests are you all getting, and how frequently? And what about the false positive issue? Thank you in advance for all info. It frightens me that I could have something going on and not find out about it until it is too late. Rachel

Posts.Title: What tests do you get after all treatment is over?

Posts.Content: Dear Colazione, Of course it's ok that you start a new post. I'd like to welcome you to the board. I don't understand about the girl in your class - does she have 2 weeks to live? Good grief, please tell us what that is. I don't think that 16 is too young to have breast cancer, but I think that it is very rare for someone at your age. However, it can happen. So it is good that you are asking questions. This is a good time for you to learn to do breast self exams. And, no matter what we tell you here, this would probably be a good time to go to your doctor or find a gynecologist that you like, so you feel comfortable asking her questions as well. And just because you are young, don't let any doctor pooh pooh your legitimate concerns because you are young. Dappling is when the skin on your breast is, well, not wrinkled exactly, but maybe a bit dented, dimpled or ripple-y. Your breast should be pretty uniformly filled out, sort of rounded, without dips or dents or ripples, no matter if you are big or small breasted. Many women have breasts that don't match eachother exactly in size or shape, but the consistency and feel of them should be fairly similar. I also used to have that yellow stuff, like little grains or something, in my nipples, when I was young. It wasn't anything for me. I cannot tell you about the hard things you are feeling, it's hard to know exactly what that is. Some women have alot of benign (not cancerous) cysts, which are lumps that you may be able to feel. Usually, lumps are not cancer, but sometimes they are, so you have to get a doctor to look at them. Here's what I suggest for you to do. Go to a female gynecologist who is known for being nice and pleasant. Ask her to do a breast exam, and ask her to tell you how to do one on your own. Show her the places that you are worried about. Ask her about breast texture, and cysts. If there is anything at all that is wrong, she will take action. My theory is, don't worry, don't freak, go see an expert. Be well and healthy! Rachel

Posts.Title: Hello. Could you help me?

Posts.Content: I had 5 1/2 weeks of radiation and was not tired at all. No, correction, I took exactly 2 naps during the whole time! Worked throughout, too. No side effects except the skin burn. For about 2 weeks after radiation (and probably one week before it ends), the irradiated area will probably be burned, like a bad sunburn. Get her doctor to prescribe silver sulfadiazine for the burning, and alternate that with the moisturizer. She will not want to wear anything tight or scratchy until the skin goes back to normal, so she should prepare clothing that is soft, and bra/bra substitutes that are very comfortable. I don't think the drive should be anything different than it would be under normal circumstances. However, she should not be exposing the irradiated area to the sun, or at least not without lots of sunblock (ask the doctor!), so perhaps some light cover ups will be helpful. I'm sure that you will both be pleasantly surprised at how easy radiation is.
